title.narrative: Mission against impunity and corruption in Honduras
Missionen mot straffrihet och korruption i Honduras

description.narrative: Improve the quality of services delivered by the justice system of Honduras in the prevention and fight against corruption and impunity in the country.

MACCIH, The Mission to Support the Fight against Corruption and Impunity in Honduras, is an important opportunity to address the combat to Impunity and Corruption, and support Human Rights defenders in Honduras. MACCIH is also a high priority initiative for the State and society of Honduras and the General Secretariat of the American Organization of States.
The Honduran Government invited the GS/OAS, in June 2015, to facilitate a process of national dialogue with the aim of building a mechanism to fight against corruption and impunity in the country.
On January 19, 2016, MACCIH was established through an agreement signed between the GS/and the Government of Honduras. MACCIH is part of the Department of Sustainable Democracy and Special Missions (“DSDSM”) of the Secretary for Strengthening Democracy of the GS/OAS.
The MACCIH-OAS has a four year mandate (2016-2020) MACCIH has a four-year mandate, 2016-2020, to improve the quality of the Honduran justice system, as well as to prevent and combat impunity and corruption in Honduras.

Organisationen för Amerikanska Staters Generalsekretariat (GS/OAS) har inkommit med en ansökan till Sveriges Ambassad i Guatemala om finansiellt stöd till Missionen för stöd till arbetet mot korruption och straffrihet i Honduras (MACCIH) för perioden 2017 – 2019.
MACCIH är en organisation som etablerades genom ett avtal mellan GS/OAS och Honduras regering den 19 januari 2016. MACCIH tillhör OAS’s avdelning för hållbar demokrati och särskilda missioner (DSDSM) under sekretariatet för stärkande av demokrati hos GS/OAS.
MACCIH har ett fyra år långt mandat, 2016-2020, för att förbättra kvaliteten i det Honduranska rättssystemet, samt för att förebygga och bekämpa straffrihet och korruption i Honduras. Insatsen bygger på antagandet att det behövs en extern internationell aktör för att på ett trovärdigt sätt kunna bidra till nedmonteringen av korrupta nätverk inom staten och att stärka rättsstatens institutioner. MACCIHs internationella experter arbetar sida vid sida med honduranska åklagare och domare i att undersöka och lagföra korruptionsfall. MACCIH genomför också utvärderingar och föreslår reformer för att stärka rättssystemet och finansiering av politiska partier.
UM Guatemala ansvarar för uppföljning av insatsen då Sida delegerat medel för insatser inom anslagspost 13, Särskilda insatser för mänskliga rättigheter och demokratisering, i syfte att säkra internationell närvaro och ge stöd för mänskliga rättigheter och demokrati i Honduras och El Salvador.

description.narrative: MACCIH strengthen the work of the Integrated Teams on the Honduran Public Prosecutor Office, which bring together the Mission’s international experts with the officials of the Special Prosecution Unit to Fight Corruption-Related Impunity of the Honduran Attorney General’s Office (UFECIC-MP). These efforts, carried out significant results: the first trial for a case brought to the court by UFECIC-MP – the “First Lady’s Petty Cash” case - started in March 2019, and five other cases received a favorable resolution at their initial hearing. UFECIC-MP issued indictments in seven (7) other cases, and is currently working with the Mission on twenty (20) lines of investigation of high-level corruption cases. These cases feed into the National Anti-Corruption Jurisdiction, which establishment was also supported by MACCIH-OAS in 2017. MACCIH-OAS presented, in February 2019, a revised version of the bill on effective collaboration (plea bargaining law), incorporating into a single text elements of two different bills presented in 2017, as well as the recommendations of the Supreme Court of Justice. Plea bargaining has proven to be an important tool in efforts to dismantle corruption networks in other countries. MACCIH-OAS also submitted to the Honduran government in February 2019 a draft amendment of Article 319 of the Constitution of the Republic, which establishes guarantees for judges and magistrates as a means to strengthen and ensure judicial independence. In addition, the Mission conducted a legal analysis of the reform of the Organic Law on the High Court of Auditors, raising concerns that some elements of the bill undermine the High Court of Auditors’ oversight powers as well as the Attorney General’s Office’s independence. Another key legal development was the decision issued on January 30, 2019 by the Constitutional Room of the Supreme Court of Justice to declare unconstitutional Legislative Decree No. 141- 2017, which introduced modifications to the Organic Budget Law that derived in the investigation known as Pact of Impunity. This decision follows the appeal of unconstitutionality presented by the Office of the Attorney General in February 2018 with the support of MACCIH-OAS against the Decree. Other legal initiatives previously submitted by the Mission are still under consideration by the government, or under review by Congress. In compliance with the Agreement between the GS/OAS and the Government of Honduras, the Justice Studies Center of the Americas (JSCA) presented, in March 2019, the report entitled Proposal for the Honduran Criminal Justice System in the Treatment and Management of the Causes of High Social Impact and Corruption. This comprehensive and well-documented report proposes a set of recommendations with a view to strengthening the Honduran institutions dedicated to fighting corruption while promoting respect for the human rights of defendants and victims. Consistent with the JSCA report recommendations, MACCIH-OAS has initiated discussions with the Attorney General’s Office with a view to drafting regulations on the prosecutorial career to regulate the system for entry into the Attorney General’s Office, as well as tenure, promotion, and disciplinary control. The Criminal Justice Observatory of the MACCIH-OAS took important steps toward its institutionalization, decentralization and sustainability in conjunction with participating Honduran civil society organizations and academia. The Observatory’s Provisional Committee defined and approved the procedures and regulations that will lead to the convening of the first National General Assembly in 2019. The preparation of the first biennial Report on the State of Criminal Justice has started, using as a model Costa Rica’s State of Justice Report research model. The Observatory continued to provide a venue for civil society to share ideas and acquire knowledge on the most important issues on Honduras’s anticorruption agenda through the organization of Citizens Forums. In the public security area, the Mission’s efforts led to the issuance of the Regulations of the Special Protection Unit for Judicial Branch Officials, proposed by MACCIH-OAS. This marked a milestone in the history of human rights in the country, in that the regulations established a specific Protection Unit for the very first time, with broad responsibilities not only for risk analysis but also for prevention. The National Congress approved the extension of the mandate of the Special Committee for the Vetting and Transformation of the National Police (CEDTPM, by its Spanish acronym) for a period of three years, through January 2022. The vetting and restructuring process of the National Police has been a key area of support of MACCIH-OAS since the inception of the Mission. The penitentiary strategy and penitentiary certification system proposed by the GS/OAS at the request of the Honduran government is still pending the government’s approval.
